definition:
Let $U$ be a domain in the complex numbers (resp., real numbers). A
function $f: U \longrightarrow \mathbb{C}$ (resp.,
$f: U \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}$) is [*analytic*]{} (resp., [*real
analytic*]{}) if $f$ has a Taylor series about each point $x \in U$ that
converges to the function $f$ in an open neighborhood of $x$.

On Analyticity and Holomorphicity
=================================

A complex function is analytic if and only if it is holomorphic. Because
of this equivalence, an analytic function in the complex case is often
defined to be one that is holomorphic, instead of one having a Taylor
series as above. Although the two definitions are equivalent, it is not
an easy matter to prove their equivalence, and a reader who does not yet
have this result available will have to pay attention as to which
definition of analytic is being used.
